I ask you, Fortunate One, please tell this to me.”
(But) I do not say that all ascetics and brahmins,
And he said the Buddha Nandā,
are enveloped in birth and old age:

source_sentence: **Ye sīdha diṭṭhaṁ va sutaṁ mutaṁ vā,**
translation: whoever here has given up (reliance on) what is seen,
heard, or sensed, and virtue and practices,
and has also given up all the countless (other) ways,
who, by fully knowing craving, are pollutant-free -
they don’t call them a flood.

source_sentence: **Nāhaṁ sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇāse, (nandāti bhagavā) jātijarāya nivutāti brūmī**ti nāhaṁ, nanda, sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā jātijarāya āvutā nivutā ovutā pihitā paṭicchannā paṭikujjitāti vadāmi.
translation: Yet I don’t say that all those ascetics and brahmins have gone beyond old age, they’re not concealed by birth. I say.

source_sentence: Atthi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā yesaṁ jāti ca jarāmaraṇañca pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammāti brūmi ācikkhāmi desemi paññapemi paṭṭhapemi vivarāmi vibhajāmi uttānīkaromi pakāsemīti—
translation: There are ascetics and brahmins who have given up rebirth and old age and death, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so that I’m unable to arise in the future. I declare: ‘I’m clearly declared: ‘I am the teaching.’

source_sentence: nāhaṁ sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇāse, (nandāti bhagavā) jātijarāya nivutāti brūmi.
translation: Yet I do not say that all ascetics and brahmins have a fixed destiny.

source_sentence: **Ye sīdha diṭṭhaṁ va sutaṁ mutaṁ vā, sīlabbataṁ vāpi pahāya sabban**ti ye sabbā diṭṭhasuddhiyo pahāya jahitvā pajahitvā vinodetvā byantīkaritvā anabhāvaṁ gametvā.
translation: After giving up all (working) what is seen, heard, thought, and known, he gives up all, and substaining it all, he departs, having given up all suffering.
All after giving up purity of mind,
all those who are released from all sense pleasures,
Those who have seen that cleansed purification in this way are abandoned
Those who are virtuous of virtue,
Those who have given up everyone,

source_sentence: ye sabbā sīlabbatasuddhiyo pahāya jahitvā pajahitvā vinodetvā byantīkaritvā anabhāvaṁ gametvāti—
translation: After giving up all precepts and observances, he gives up all these precepts and observances, but then, having given them up, he departs.

source_sentence: ye sīdha diṭṭhaṁ va sutaṁ mutaṁ vā, sīlabbataṁ vāpi pahāya sabbaṁ.
translation: whoever has given up (reliance on) what is seen, heard, and thought,

source_sentence: **Anekarūpampi pahāya sabban**ti anekavidhakotūhalamaṅgalena suddhiṁ visuddhiṁ parisuddhiṁ muttiṁ vimuttiṁ parimuttiṁ pahāya jahitvā pajahitvā vinodetvā byantīkaritvā anabhāvaṁ gametvāti—
translation: And after giving up all of using uncontrolled gold coins, cleansing the pure flawless, free of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable, having given up all knowledge and freedom,
and has also given up all the countless (other) ways,

source_sentence: **Taṇhaṁ pariññāya anāsavā se, te ve narā oghatiṇṇāti brūmī**ti.
translation: I say that craving is completed, without pollutants, I say.

source_sentence: **Taṇhā**ti rūpataṇhā saddataṇhā gandhataṇhā rasataṇhā phoṭṭhabbataṇhā dhammataṇhā.
translation: craving for sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts.
When craving is completely understood, one who has completely understood the three cravings and the complete understanding of craving,
and completely understanding the course of relatives,
What is the end of relatives?

source_sentence: Taṇhaṁ jānāti “ayaṁ rūpataṇhā, ayaṁ saddataṇhā, ayaṁ gandhataṇhā, ayaṁ rasataṇhā, ayaṁ phoṭṭhabbataṇhā, ayaṁ dhammataṇhā”ti jānāti passati—
translation: craving for sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts. This is craving for touches.
this is the end of relatives,
What are the three perils that completely understand?

source_sentence: Evaṁ ñātaṁ katvā taṇhaṁ tīreti aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato …pe…
translation: So you’ve done what leads to your relatives.
Regarding an escape from it:
This is the way of completely understanding.
What is the completely understanding of giving up?

source_sentence: Evaṁ tīrayitvā taṇhaṁ pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṁ gameti.
translation: So when you give up craving, get rid of it, eliminate it, and obliterate it.
for this is said by the Buddha,
“Mendicants, give up desire and greed for craving.

source_sentence: Evaṁ sā taṇhā pahīnā bhavissati ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammā”.
translation: In this way that craving will be given up, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.”
This is the end of giving up.

source_sentence: **Taṇhaṁ pariññāyā**ti taṇhaṁ imāhi tīhi pariññāhi parijānitvā.
translation: When craving is completely understood, these three cravings do so after completely understood them.
Four defilements:
the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

source_sentence: Yesaṁ ime āsavā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammā, te vuccanti anāsavā arahanto khīṇāsavā—
translation: These are the defilements that lead to the future. They’re cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.
who, by fully knowing craving, are pollutant-free -

source_sentence: **Te ve narā oghatiṇṇāti brūmī**ti ye taṇhaṁ pariññāya anāsavā, te kāmoghaṁ tiṇṇā bhavoghaṁ tiṇṇā diṭṭhoghaṁ tiṇṇā avijjoghaṁ tiṇṇā sabbasaṁsārapathaṁ tiṇṇā uttiṇṇā nitthiṇṇā atikkantā samatikkantā vītivattāti brūmi ācikkhāmi desemi paññapemi paṭṭhapemi vivarāmi vibhajāmi uttānīkaromi pakāsemīti—
translation: So I don’t tell them how to cross over the flood.

source_sentence: taṇhaṁ pariññāya anāsavāse te ve narā oghatiṇṇāti brūmi.
translation: I say that craving is completely understood, the undefiled in you,

are enveloped in birth and old age:

heard, or sensed, and virtue and practices,
and has also given up all the countless (other) ways,
who, by fully knowing craving, are pollutant-free -

source_sentence: **Ye sīdha diṭṭhaṁ va sutaṁ mutaṁ vā,**

heard, or sensed, and virtue and practices,
and has also given up all the countless (other) ways,
who, by fully knowing craving, are pollutant-free -

source_sentence: **Etan**ti tuyhaṁ vacanaṁ byappathaṁ desanaṁ anusāsanaṁ anusiṭṭhaṁ nandāmi abhinandāmi modāmi anumodāmi icchāmi sādiyāmi patthayāmi pihayāmi abhijappāmi.
translation: Living in what is beneficial for you, I’m not bowing down to you, having rejoiced in material pleasures. And I accept it.

source_sentence: Mahantaṁ sīlakkhandhaṁ esī gavesī pariyesīti mahesi …pe…

Gotama practices well:

source_sentence: **Sukittitan**ti sukittitaṁ suācikkhitaṁ sudesitaṁ supaññapitaṁ supaṭṭhapitaṁ suvivaṭaṁ suvibhattaṁ suuttānīkataṁ supakāsitaṁ.
translation: well-classed, well-restrained, well-proclaimed, well-proclaimed, well-leared, well-made, and well-proclaimed.

source_sentence: **Gotamanūpadhīkan**ti upadhī vuccanti kilesā ca khandhā ca abhisaṅkhārā ca.
translation: (They are) components that are called the aggregates, the defilements and the defilement of the corruptions.

source_sentence: Upadhippahānaṁ upadhivūpasamaṁ upadhinissaggaṁ upadhipaṭippassaddhaṁ amataṁ nibbānanti—
translation: Calmness is the vital condition for attachments; it’s the culmination of attachments, and the deathless.

source_sentence: **Ye sīdha diṭṭhaṁ va sutaṁ mutaṁ vā, sīlabbataṁ vāpi pahāya sabban**ti ye sabbā diṭṭhasuddhiyo pahāya jahitvā pajahitvā vinodetvā byantīkaritvā anabhāvaṁ gametvā.
translation: After giving up all (working) what is seen, heard, thought, and known, he gives up all, and substaining it all, he departs, having given up all suffering.
Anyone who makes purity of mindfulness well pure in mind ...

source_sentence: **Anekarūpampi pahāya sabban**ti anekavidhakotūhalamaṅgalena suddhiṁ visuddhiṁ parisuddhiṁ muttiṁ vimuttiṁ parimuttiṁ pahāya jahitvā pajahitvā vinodetvā byantīkaritvā anabhāvaṁ gametvāti—

source_sentence: **Taṇhā**ti rūpataṇhā saddataṇhā gandhataṇhā rasataṇhā phoṭṭhabbataṇhā dhammataṇhā.

When craving is completely understood, one who has completely understood the three cravings and the complete understanding of craving,
and completely understanding the course of relatives,

he knows craving—

source_sentence: ayaṁ rūpataṇhā, ayaṁ saddataṇhā, ayaṁ gandhataṇhā, ayaṁ rasataṇhā, ayaṁ phoṭṭhabbataṇhā, ayaṁ dhammataṇhāti jānāti passati—

this is the end of relatives,

source_sentence: Evaṁ ñātaṁ katvā taṇhaṁ tīreti aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato ītito upaddavato bhayato upasaggato calato pabhaṅguto addhuvato atāṇato aleṇato asaraṇato asaraṇībhūtato rittato tucchato suññato anattato ādīnavato vipariṇāmadhammato asārakato aghamūlato vadhakato vibhavato sāsavato saṅkhatato mārāmisato jātidhammato jarādhammato byādhidhammato maraṇadhammato sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammato saṅkilesadhammato samudayato atthaṅgamato assādato ādīnavato nissaraṇato tīreti—
translation: After seeing this, you’re afflicted, suffering, and produced by craving. And as diseased, they dart from sickness, as an abscess, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self.
This is the way of completely understanding.
What is the completely understanding of giving up?

source_sentence: Evaṁ tīrayitvā taṇhaṁ pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṁ gameti—
translation: After giving up craving, they give up craving, get rid of, eliminate, and obliterate those thoughts.
This is the end of giving up.

source_sentence: **Taṇhaṁ pariññāyā**ti taṇhaṁ imāhi tīhi pariññāhi parijānitvā.
translation: When craving is completely understood, these three cravings do so after completely understood them.
Four defilements:
the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

source_sentence: Yesaṁ ime āsavā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammā, te vuccanti anāsavā arahanto khīṇāsavā.
translation: Those who have given up the defilements that should be cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.
who has completely understood craving, without pollutants, and so am I.

source_sentence: **Brūmī**ti ye taṇhaṁ pariññāya anāsavā, ahampi te kāmoghaṁ tiṇṇā bhavoghaṁ tiṇṇā diṭṭhoghaṁ tiṇṇā avijjoghaṁ tiṇṇā sabbasaṁsārapathaṁ tiṇṇā uttiṇṇā nitthiṇṇā atikkantā samatikkantā vītivattāti brūmi vadāmīti—
translation: I say that, when it comes to the crossroads, has crossed over the flood and cuts off the flood, bondservants, workers, and staff; and anywhere because I have crossed over the flood. May I say that there are ascetics of other religions, but say.
